I suspect that a succinct statement as to the surrounding facts will be helpful and appreciative of the full import of the question before the Court.

The petitioner is an illiterate person and a poor person and in April 1961 was engaged as a farm laborer by a resident of Lafayette Parish, Louisiana and the employer in question happened to be the father of one of the arresting deputies who arrested the petitioner on the charge of -- in question.

The agreement for or rather control in a working arrangement was that, the petitioner was to be paid $4 a day for his services and to be provided with his food and also lodging, the lodging consisting of a small building approximately 8 by 10 in which he was permitted to reside.
The employer paid the petitioner for about a month and thereafter discontinued paying his wages.
The petitioner continued to ask payment, but on each occasion he was told that he would be paid later.
As a consequence of course the petitioner was, had no funds with which to leave and seek out other employment and he lived in virtual peonage for approximately eight moths.

And then on one day approximately eight months after the initial engagement of his services the -- an argument arose between the employer and petitioner as to chores to be performed as a result of which the employer told him to leave his premises.

He agreed to do this and he asked permission of the employer to leave his personal belongings in this little one room shack that he occupied, his small amount of clothing that he had and this permission was granted.

And he took leave to go to Nevada in search of employment where one of his sisters lived but because of his lack of skill he was unable to obtain employment in Nevada and returned Lafayette Parish and on his return however, he found other employment on a farm not to far removed from his previous employment.

He returned to his shack to pick up his meager belongings and night time was had already come about and after he was in this little building for approximately ten minutes he heard a rap at the door and upon opening the door there were four deputies from the Sheriff's office there to arrest him.
They told him that there were there to arrest him on the instruction of his employer on a ground that he was trespassing.
He surrendered himself to them and they brought him to Parish jail.

turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: Were you ever consulted?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I was not consulted at all.
In fact the petitioner states that he asked to call me on the telephone and they refused to permit him to do so.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: That he was brought before -- they transferred the charge from the state district court to the city court. I say they, I mean the Assistant District Attorney then took the charge from the Parish --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) back to the city court?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I don't know exactly just how he did this except that I think he filed another charge before the city court rising out of same facts or circumstance because I see in June thereafter he dismisses the state charge, well whatever method he used, I really can't tell Your Honor at this time.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: (Inaudible) file a new charge.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: He apparently filed a new charge in city court, I would --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The identical charge was now in the city court, is that --

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: The identical charge rising of the same factual situation.
Apparently couldn't transfer it because it had been Nolle prosequi in the District Court.
So together, the Assistant District Attorney together with the sheriff, took our client out of jail without our knowledge, brought him to city court and then had him enter plea of guilty.

Now then the Assistant District Attorney went to the city judge and told – recommended to the city judge that the punishment to be for the time served and in carrying out the recommendation of the Assistant District Attorney, this is the sentence which the city judge imposed upon him, time served –

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well does the -- you know it seems to me this is rather important what charge he was -- he plead guilty to, if plead guilty to this one, isn't this a state statute, the state vagrancy statute?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir.
He plead guilty to the same charge Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is the city statue like this, city ordinance like this?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I don't know, but there is -- but he was --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Has the city got jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: It has jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh it has jurisdiction –

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: It has jurisdiction.
But this -- as I recall, this was the identical charge that was filed against him in the city court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: According the record of the -- oh no, of course not because all this happen after (Inaudible) while the petition was pending here.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir Your Honor.
It's appended to our supplemental brief.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well is the charge itself –

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Well the charge, I don't believe that the charge is, but the affidavit of the city judge as to what transpired is appended to it, which is substantially --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, may I just ask?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.
Here is what the city judge states Your Honor.
He states that the charges were transferred from the docket of the 15th District Court and for the Parish of Lafayette, Louisiana.
One charge was for the crime of vagrancy and the second charge was for commission of an act of simple battery.
So it was -- he considered it a transfer even though the original charge was not Nolle prosequi.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was it a transfer of the same charge?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Transfer of the same charge.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the only thing I don't follow Mr. Simon -- I though you indicated -- you made a motion to quash the information, that's never been --

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Never been ruled upon.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, does that information still extend, is that still outstanding?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: It has dismissed as June the 4th, the District Attorney null -- moved for the Nolle prosequi.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What did the city judge do then?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: City judge entertained the plea and on the recommendation of the Assistant District Attorney imposed a sentence that was equivalent or equal to the time he had spent in the jail, so he let him go.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that – then why would you Nolle prosequi a --

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I don't know.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why would you cancel the information after that, I mean it's all -- you don't Nolle prosequi information to somebody who has served his sentence, do you?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Your Honor the District Attorney would be able to answer that question, I certainly can't.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: (Inaudible) in the city court, so then we went back five days later, I gather, I all I know is what is in the record.
He then went back to the state court five days later and dismissed the charge, which is very often done by the District Attorney.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: It was the same charge but it was dismissed.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Is that a different court?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes a different court.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Charged with battery when the first one didn't charge?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I suppose, he felt that he was -- on the minutes of the Court that should be somehow disposed off and that's what he did.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now I gather Mr. Simon that at the time we passed on your petition for certiorari and granted it, none of the facts of any event after March was before us, was it?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And everything -- and what we agreed to review was a judgment, sort of judgment whatever it maybe of the Supreme Court of Louisiana which denied you the review of the denial of habeas corpus and the application for original habeas corpus, the application for certiorari, prohibition and mandamus, that's what we agreed to review, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now how can we in the face of what happened after March?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Well, Your Honor my response to that is that this plea of guilty was procured through the coercive effect of an illegal detainment or detention of this petitioner and that it was procured through the illegal and relentless conduct and acts of state officials.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible) before the state supreme court Mr. Simon.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Review of what, Justice Harlan?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The plea of guilty, the coerced plea of guilty?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: No sir we did not enter the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: So that the Louisiana Supreme Court does not have these facts before it.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Not that plea, no sir Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) by which that might have been reviewed, I gather now he had been released, he was out.
So I suppose habeas corpus, couldn't proceed on habeas corpus, but is there -- isn't there some procedure in Louisiana by which you could have attacked that coerced guilty plea?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I can think of none.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, then how can we do it Mr. Simon?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I can think of no procedure.
My position to this Your Honor is that we'd be rewarding the state officials with illegal conduct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I agree it's rather outrageous, it seems to me, but I don't know if we can do that.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Furthermore Your Honor, in my judgment a plea of guilty is the ultimate confession known to our courts and under Upshaw and McNab decision the courts have held that under these circumstances where a confession is procured through the coercive influence or illegal detention that confession is an absolute nullity and cannot be used against it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But those cases apply only in federal prosecutions.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Oh I think that the rights not to be illegally detained is part of the concept of our liberty in the Fourteenth Amendment and where one is induced and coerced into pleading guilty or making an ultimate confession of guilty through this process --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This may --

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: They would be --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Believe me I am not against you –

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I understand you.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) because this certainly sounds outrageous to me.
The difficulty is how do you escape -- this is utterly moot, that is what we agreed to review, is that any longer open?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: It's my position Your Honor that the plea is an absolute nullity and the Court could ignore it as such because it was procured contrary to the constitutional rights of the petitioner and therefore it can't operate as bar to review the basic liberty questions presented to the Court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible) proceeding in the Louisiana by which you could -- no collateral post conviction proceeding by which you could have attacked this coerced plea?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I suspect Your Honor that at anytime the party could file an action to secure some kind of an injunction to erase this conviction from the record (Inaudible) illegally procured that would be available –-

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But you've never done it.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I have never done it, I have never had the occasion to do it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The honest trouble is you are asking us to pass on questions here apart from what Mr. Justice Brennan has said that the -- no Louisiana courts have ever faced them –-

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Actually Your Honor will get to that question only when you entertain the motion to dismiss because the question is moot, and I don't that --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, this is a different question as to whether we have any jurisdiction apart from all this.
These questions are never raised before any Louisiana court.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: The constitutional questions were raised Your Honor, which --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I'm talking about the coerced plea, the illegal detention, all those things were never raised apparently before the --

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Your Honor the illegal detention was raised up to the point of March the 9th, they were raised, that he was denied of all of his legal rights, the night of the hearing, he was denied of the right to be brought before committing magistrate, he was denied of having the right to have the sheriff respond in writing to his writ, he was denied of the right to a preliminary examination once been granted.
The Court granted a relief not prayed for by the state in that it recalled it's order of preliminary examination, where they had only asked the hearing be --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That has been -- makes it difficult for us to do anything about it because he is now out of jail.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Well, I –

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And we have got before us the question of the ratio of this coerced plea under the circumstances that you've narrated because that isn't involved in this petition and furthermore it has never been passed upon by any state court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible) ask us to declare the regulatory statute constitutional.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Precisely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which -- for violation of which he pleaded guilty.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes indeed Your Honor, that is my -- and I might say this, its rare that you are going to ever have the constitutionality of a vagrancy statute presented to you because I dare say there are very few people who will remain in jail under these circumstances long enough to give you the opportunity to do so.
In fact may I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that's the problem that your client didn't need it.

This is a habeas corpus proceeding and the function of a habeas corpus proceeding is to be freed from unlawful custody, and this man is not in custody, that's the -- isn't that the basic, a basic problem.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: No, not necessarily.

We -- the basis for -- that is one of the basis, yes Your Honor, of course we applied also for writ of review in which we attacked the constitutionality of the statute and that question is basically still before the Court.
In my Judgment perhaps habeas corpus had been affected by his release, I'm not certain that it has but we also prayed for relief that the conviction itself be erased from the records of all courts.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, where did you ever pray for that, until you got here?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes in my --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is something that -- generally you have to begin some where else, you can't just come to this Court do novo and say erase the conviction.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: I was looking for my original petition to the Court, but returning to the question of his plea, I think that the state supplies this Court with enough evidence to treat the plea as an absolute nullity.
For example, they have attached the affidavit of the Deputy Sheriff Mr. Clarence Tibado in which he outlines what transpired.
I have a brief quotation from it at page three of my supplemental brief Your Honors.

Now, in reciting what took place, this Deputy Sheriff stated that the accused -- that the petitioner had called my office for purpose of talking to me but I wasn't there, of course the accused denies this, he says he called my office after he had entered the plea because they wouldn't let him use the telephone before, but in any event the deputy says, quotes the language, quotes the statement that the petitioner is supposed to have made it to my secretary, “I don't know who he talked to but he said, “if you don't do something about it today, I will go plea guilty because I cannot stand the jail no more.
He hung up the phone and I put him back in jail.”

Now this is absolute proof of the worst type of coercion that any state official may exert against a prisoner and any confession obtained under those circumstance certainly should not be given the dignity and validity of operation to bar this Court from reviewing questions of constitutional law which was probably before it at all times previous to that time.
Well, it's you before Your Honor in connection --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Under the State Court and they denied your relief on these set of facts and they have actually established and of course you have a constitutional claim of the first order which we could review but those questions aren't here.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Your Honor, we don't ask this Court as such to release him from jail, but we are asking this Court to pass on a validity of the initial charges that was filed against him and now which is a matter of public record and in connection with which he has been forced to enter a plea of guilty.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: That's quite true.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: In this case, it's here, they have been (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: There is no question that the charge itself has been dismissed but then again we have this proposition, is this Court going to be hamstrung by the conduct of state official, they have been dismissed because now the state has found it propitious to dismiss these things, after the state --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: That was all done before we took jurisdiction you say, so you had your plea in the other case in May, then you had your dismissal in June of this case and then we granted cert in October.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: In fact Your Honors granted cert in February of 1963.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Way after what?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Way after this.
But the issue --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, there wouldn't be any -- wouldn't come in under case at trial, we were frustrated of any jurisdiction because we had no jurisdiction, we had granted the cert.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: But I can't convince myself that the act of noting jurisdiction or not is material in relationship to the basic question involved and that is that here state officials are attempting to profit by their absolutely illegal conduct in relationship to the liberty questions involved in the detention of this prisoner.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, I'm with you on that.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: And if the Court --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: I have to look at the jurisdiction whether – so you haven't had any Louisiana Court pass on those problems or on whether or not the confession was coerced or rather their plea was coerced.
So while your statement is very appealing to what this man suffered and I would like to help you on it, I don't know how we could under our sit out, under our jurisdiction, it's included in our --

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir, if this Court however were to hold that this plea is an absolute nullity then all of the basic questions presented originally are still before the Court.
It's a question of weather or not –-

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Louisiana hasn't held that have they, that hasn't been taken to Louisiana and for our jurisdiction you have to take to the State Court.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Well then of course we are talking -- this question arises only in connection with state's motion to dismiss because it's moot and it's something which was created -- is their own creation and it's not -- it was involved in the time the application was filed and I don't --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible) Court to declare to release you, to release your client from custody because of the unconstitutionality of the Louisiana statute.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir, one of the –-

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you were saying that was one of your ground, that you were being – your client was being detained, his detention was illegal under the statute.
You still got that claim.

Now if this man were still in jail, had been sentenced to jail and was still in jail, you would still have a claim that he was being detained by the State of Louisiana under an unconstitutional statue.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes I would.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the fact that he had pleaded guilty and then convicted would have changed the nature of your claim, was it the illegal detention.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Not to the slightest degree Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the only thing that really makes it weak here is I suppose the fact that he isn't detained, he has been released, he's been released and also the fact that there maybe some real questions here as to whether you adequately raised your vagueness argument (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are there any consequences that hangover persist after a release of a prisoner, after he has served his sentences or any disabilities, any civil disabilities in Louisiana?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Not for a misdemeanor, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: But he has a criminal record which I think this Court certainly could reach out and clear this for him without him having to go through another procedure to bring it before the Court.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir they concede.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes that's -- which --

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Which incidentally Your Honor, a prosecution from misdemeanor maybe based upon an affidavit, you don't have to have a bill of information, yes.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir, and I'm glad Your Honor mentioned that because it gives raise to collateral question, and it points up the fact that the sole reason for the which the state did file this Bill of Information was an attempt to defeat petitioner's right to preliminary examination and this particular ground was used by the Trail Judge to deny, preliminary examination, may I elaborate further?

Under the preliminary examination statute before the filing of the Bill of Information either the state or the accused has the absolute unconditional right to a preliminary hearing which calls upon the state to show probable cause for holding -- detaining a person.
After Bill of Information or indictment has been filed and it is discretionary with the Court, we filed this application before the charters, before the bill was filed.
Then when it came up for hearing the District Attorney asked for a continuous to the next date.

The following day is when he filed the Bill of Information then he took the position and therefore it was discretionary and the Judge adopted this position and then did not deny a preliminary examination, but recalled his previous order, a request -- where there had been no request for such action by the Court.
So I just thought I'd point this out.

Then should the Court want me to go into the constitutional question, I'd be very happy to, which we have raised and it is our contention that this statue is unconstitutional for two basic reasons, one is that it is so vague as to run counter to the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and also that it denies Equal Protection.
Now, of course --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes Your Honor there is no subsection eight.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And where did you present these precise grounds to the Supreme Court of Louisiana?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What page?

turn.text: I made just one -- I'm afraid I'm in error there Your Honor.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark

turn.text: Didn't say that what the statue is vague or not, said the charge is no criminal offense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon

turn.text: Yes sir it is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Rather than what you ask the Supreme Court to pass on in paragraph 26.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Rely on what you say in page 27 of your draft brief where you ask the statue be declared --

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes that's correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But my trouble -- let me put this question to you, let's assume that this was properly raised or was raised in what was before the Supreme Court, at that stage of the matter the case had not been tried, it was simply attacking the indictment.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And the denial results in the case going back for a trial at that stage.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: How is that a final order that we can review?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Your Honor for the reason that in our procedure in Louisiana, a question which is patent on the face of the record maybe raised at any time.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well I'm talking about our jurisdiction because theoretically this case is after denial could have gone back to the Trial Court and if your client had not pleaded guilty it could have been tried, he might have been acquitted.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: That's quite true.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: As a matter then there would have been nothing for this Court obviously that you would bring up.
My question is how is this a final order at that stage?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: It' a final order insofar as it finally disposes of petitioner's right to habeas corpus.
It finally disposes of petitioner's right to preliminary examination and it finally disposes of his right not to be prosecuted on an absolutely illegal statue.
And those are -- all which of in my judgment --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You design it from the standpoint of your law, but we have to -- our jurisdiction is submitted by our federal statues to bind orders.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Then I'm afraid I can't answer the question otherwise Your Honor.
But it is final insofar as our judgment of the case is concerned because it didn't appraise of these constitutional rights.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: You raised your constitutional (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that was in the Trial Court.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: We've all -- in our prayers as Mr. Justice Harlan pointed out we expressly ask for that particular remedy, but in my judgment Your Honor the statute is void for vagueness and I started to point out while vagrancy prosecutions in themselves are not serious offenses, they become a major crime when the Court considers that the use of this statute is very widespread throughout the nation and it constitutes a very serious abuse in our judgment on the liberty of rights of citizens.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This doesn't seem to me to be the vagrancy statute in the sense I ordinarily understand the vagrancy statute with all the specificity.

They could have -- without using the word vagrancy I gather this statute could be read as making an offense by any person found in or in any structure, movable vessel or private (Inaudible) of being able to account for his lawful presence therein, that doesn't sound to me ordinarily like a vagrancy.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: That's a species of vagrancy statute Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Sounds criminal trespass more, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: It sounds like that, but you don't -- the difference is, and that's where you equality clause comes in, the difference is there is nothing intrinsically criminal in what you are doing and they charge you and prosecute you and punish you for the status you occupy.
There is nothing inherently criminal about just being there.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well there isn't, but the statute says that you have to be unlawfully there, and that's criminal.
So if I go home tonight and find somebody in my house who is a visitor, obviously he is not guilty of anything, but if I find somebody there who has broken in, he is unlawfully there.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: But the charge usually is for what he has been guilty, the conduct for which he has been guilty.
This charge does not relate to conduct.
If he is there, then they coupled this with not being able to account for his lawful presence therein.

This is what is offensive which is not an act of conduct as such, but rather a punishment for the status which you occupy, and it is vague if Your Honors please for the reason that the language itself, the terms employed are too general, there are no standards by which you can determine the meaning without being able to account.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: He could be.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But how?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Well who determines what is the proper accounting, that's the point.
There are no standards.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whether or not it is lawful and what's so unlawful about walking down the street?

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: But the statue doesn't say that you have to show --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Lawful, that's the unlawful presence.

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: Well for example if the judge doesn't feel that you have given the satisfactory accounting, then of course you would be guilty of it.

It calls upon you to affirmatively take a position and explain your conduct, which embraces another question which I raise in this connection, that is that it calls upon an accused to affirmatively state why is there and if he does not do that then of course he has failed to account for his lawful presence, thus he is deprived of invoking the Fifth Amendment should he decide to do so.

And of course this is a right which is common to all persons charged with crime in the state of Louisiana and to that extent and of course he would be deprived of a constitutional right and he would be deprived of equal protection.

turn.speaker: arthur_j_goldberg
turn.label: Justice Arthur J. Goldberg
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_minos_simon
turn.label: Mr. J. Minos Simon
turn.text: That's correct.
You could extend this further.
Suppose that Hannah is on property of another and they stop him and he says, well the reason I'm here and I'm looking for my homes, now is that illegal?
You're not charged of trespassing or a beggar might be vague.

He might say he wants to eat something or an artist might be vague, he may want to capture the scenery on canvass, suppose he gives that accounting to whoever arrests him, is that a satisfactory accounting?
There is no way by which we make that determination.
Now time then becomes important also.
Should the same reason, should the same accounting be given, say at 5 o'clock in the afternoon, is that reasonable?
If it's given at 12 o'clock at night or 2 o'clock in the morning, does it become unlawful and why does it become unlawful?
There are no standards by which a judgment as those things may be made.

There are no standards by which the courts may be guided in this interpretation of this particular statute and so the citizen is left in the precarious position of having to speculate as to what the statute does mean and what is does not mean and he must speculate it at the peril of his liberty.
And I think repeatedly this Court has held that such a statute when so vague is absolutely unconstitutional is depriving party of due process.

Now also I might state that the classification itself, the theory behind the vagrancy statute Your Honor is that part is found in this type of situation or not doing anything intrinsically criminal but because of a status they occupy or the mode of existence which they pursue, they create a ferment that the breach undefined crimes and therefore they should be punished.

Well we submit that the classification itself is unreasonable, it's discrimination that is not reasonably related to the purpose of the statue because there is evidence to demonstrate that the theory correct and therefore yes.
